awd_titl_txt: Substrate-Enhanced reactivity of pristine graphene in cycloaddition reactions
awd_abstract_narration:
Professors Mingdi Yan and Lawrence Wolf of the University of Massachusetts Lowell are supported by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular, and Nanochemistry (MSN) Program of the Division of Chemistry to develop experimental and computationally guided approaches to enhance the reactivity of pristine graphene (a defect-free single layer, two-dimensional carbon material).  The integration of theory with experiment provides a comprehensive, fundamental understanding of the reactions leading to the acceleration of discovery.  The results have a direct impact on the practical utilization of this material, which exhibit extraordinary mechanical, electrical and thermal properties.  Pristine graphene has the potential to impact many technologically important applications, such as in display screens, nanoelectronics, solar cells, and various others.  Pristine graphene offers advantages over other forms of graphene, which are either oxidized or contain many defects.  The computational modeling techniques used are incorporated in the curriculum of new computational chemistry courses offered to both undergraduate and graduate students. The students involved in the project receive training in research planning and evaluation through individualized development plans. Under-represented and female undergraduate students are recruited to participate in the project. 

This project aims to expand the chemical space of pristine graphene. Specifically, the impacts of substrate and interface on the reactivity of pristine graphene in cycloaddition reactions is investigated both experimentally and computationally. Pristine graphene is fabricated on different surfaces by chemical vapor deposition or by transfer. Cycloaddition reactions, with initial focus on the (2+1) cycloaddition with perfluoroaryl azides, are carried out and the products are characterized.  The study aims to shed light on the relationship between the reactivity of graphene and its supporting substrate interface.  The reactivity of pristine graphene in other cycloaddition reactions is also a subject of this investigation.  The theoretical underpinnings of the cycloaddition substrate/reactivity relationships with pristine graphene is established using density functional theory through the development and application of modern reactivity models.  Pristine graphene is fairly inert chemically due to the large resonance stabilization resulting from the delocalization of its conjugated pi electrons over the entire two-dimensional network. Overcoming these inherent reactivity challenges offers the ability to introduce into pristine graphene well-defined functionalities.  Other benefits include modulating graphene solubility and bandgap, and enabling its integration into high performance composite materials and devices.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The overall objective of this project has been to investigate how the reactivity of graphene towards cycloaddition reactions is enhanced by metal substrates. Functionalization of graphene in this way is particularly attractive with respect to atom economy, rapid construction of structural complexity through the formation of multiple bonds simultaneously, and reaction reversibility in the case of Diels-Alder reactions.

To achieve the substrate-enhanced reactivity, fabrication of monolayer graphene was first required. This fabrication has been accomplished through chemical vapor deposition (CVD). The final optimized method involves transferring monolayer graphene on copper followed by subsequent transfer to other substrates including Ni and SiO2 using an in-house built CVD apparatus. With this optimized method developed, the cycloaddition reactions could then be performed on substrate supported monolayer graphene.

The first cycloaddition performed was aziridination using perfluorophenyl azide (PFPA). Reaction progress and kinetics were determined using Raman spectroscopy. The kinetics revealed a fast reaction with a strong dependence on the substrate support with a reactivity trend following graphene supported on Ni (G/Ni), followed by G/Cu and then G/SiO2. The results are supported by quantum simulations revealing that strong charge transfer from Ni to graphene leads to enhanced bond formation with the electron deficient intermediate nitrene. These important results demonstrated that the reactivity of pristine, defect-free graphene can be modulated by the use of metal substrates towards cycloaddition reactions.

The outcomes from the aziridination project gave us a firm foundation for investigating an arguably more synthetically useful cycloaddition, the Diels-Alder reaction. The Diels-Alder reaction, a classic cycloaddition reaction involving a diene and a dienophile to form a cyclohexene, is among the most versatile organic reactions. Theories have predicted thermodynamically unfavorable DA reactions on pristine graphene owing to its low chemical reactivity. We hypothesized that metals like Ni could enhance the reactivity of graphene towards the DA reactions through charge transfer analogous to aziridination.

A similar experimental setup to aziridination was used for performing the Diels-Alder reaction. We explored multiple reactant partners which including 2,3-dimethoxy butadiene (DMBD) and maleic anhydride (MAH). The reactions were monitored using Raman spectroscopy and the kinetics did indicate again a strong substrate dependence on the reactivity. Unusual temperature effects were also observed. The reactivity trend did follow the order of G/Ni, G/Cu, G/SiO2 for both reactants. Quantum chemical simulations were used to establish the overall mechanism, reveal the role of the substrate at the electronic level, and the predicted reactivity trends support the experimental results. The outcomes of this project show that the Diels-Alder reaction can indeed be accelerated using metal substrates and provides a foundation for functionalizing graphene through other Diels-Alder reactions.  

The project has trained doctoral students in multidisciplinary research of both experiments and computation. The project has also facilitated the training of high school students through summer research. Students involved in the project have either found employment in STEM fields after obtaining a PhD degree or have gone to colleges majoring in STEM subjects. The project has facilitated the development of a computation course for graduate/senior undergraduate students and allowed us to participate in outreach activities to local K-12 students.

 


Last Modified: 11/17/2022
Modified by: Mingdi Yan
